para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this article, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Authorization to Proceed.
para.text: "Authorization to Proceed" means approval from the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation that:
permits an applicant to complete alterations to a historic structure, as proposed in the application;
is issued by the Director or the Director's designee following the Commission's approval;
includes a description of the proposed work; and
may be approved by the Commission or issued by the Director with conditions.

para.heading: Building Official.
para.text: "Building Official" has the meaning stated in § 103.1 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Commission; CHAP.
para.text: "Commission" or "CHAP" means the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation established under this article.

para.heading: Conservation District.
para.text: "Conservation District" or "Historical Conservation District" means an area designated as a Conservation District under subtitle 3 {"Designation of Preservation Districts and Conservation Districts"} of this Article.

para.heading: Demolition.
para.text: "Demolition" includes "demolition by neglect", which means neglect in the maintenance or repair of a structure, resulting in any of the following conditions:
the deterioration of any architectural feature so as to create or permit the creation of a hazardous or unsafe condition;
the deterioration of walls or other vertical supports;
the deterioration of roofs or other horizontal members;
the deterioration of chimneys;
the deterioration or crumbling of plaster or mortar; or
the ineffective waterproofing of walls, roofs, and foundations, including broken windows and doors.

para.heading: District.
para.text: "District" means a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or a Historical Conservation District.

para.heading: Executive Director; Director.
para.text: "Executive Director" or "Director" means the Executive Director of the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Historical and Architectural Preservation District; Preservation District.
para.text: "Historical and Architectural Preservation District" or "Preservation District" means an area designated as a Historical and Architectural Preservation District under Subtitle 3 {"Designation of Historical Districts and Historical Conservation Districts"}, of this article.

para.heading: Landmark.
para.text: "Landmark" means a property listed on a Landmark List.

para.heading: Landmark List.
para.text: "Landmark List" means either or both of the following, as established and maintained under Subtitle 4 {"Designation of Landmarks"}, of this article:
the Landmark List: Exteriors; and
the Landmark List: Public Interiors.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this article "person" also includes, except as used in § 9-4 {"Criminal penalties"} of this article, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Potential Landmark.
para.text: "Potential Landmark" means a property listed on a Potential-Landmark List.

para.heading: Potential-Landmark List.
para.text: "Potential-Landmark List" means either or both of the following, as established and maintained under Subtitle 5 {"Designation of Potential Landmarks"}, of this article:
the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors; and
the Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors.

para.heading: Public interior.
para.text: "Public interior" means any part of a structure's interior that is determined by the Commission to be:
customarily open or accessible to the public; and
of historical or architectural significance.

para.heading: Regulated alteration.
para.text: "Regulated alteration" means any addition, alteration or other action described in § 8-2(a) {"Building permit required: Exterior structures"} or § 8-2(b) {"Building permit required: Public interiors"}, as the case may be, of this article.

para.heading: Structure.
para.text: "Structure" means any creation of humans or nature.

annotation.text: Ord. 22-125 repealed this section, which contained rules of interpretation that have been superseded by uniform Code-wide rules codified in the newly enacted General Provisions Article.

For the text of all of the Code-wide rules of interpretation, see General Provisions Article, §§ 1-201 (In general), 1-203 (Gender), 1-204 (Mandatory, prohibitory, and permissive terms), 1-205 (Singular and plural), 1-208 (Captions or headers), 1-209 (Editor’s or Revisor’s Notes), 1-211 (Effect of repeal or amendment of statute), 1-212 (References to other laws), 1-214 (Severability), and 1-301 et seq. (Time Computations).

para.heading: Areas and structures to be preserved.

para.text: Baltimore City contains a number of significant areas within which are located various buildings and other structures that contribute to the historical or architectural significance of the area. The preservation of these areas is appropriate and necessary for the educational, cultural, economic, and general welfare of the public.

Baltimore City contains an even greater number of individually significant buildings and other structures that have special historical or architectural significance. The preservation of these individual structures is equally appropriate and necessary for the educational, cultural, economic, and general welfare of the public.

para.heading: Need for controls or restrictions.
para.text: To preserve these significant areas and individual structures, it is necessary to impose controls and restrictions on or in connection with them.

para.heading: Creation of CHAP.
para.text: For these purposes, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore has enacted this article, establishing the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation and vesting it with the powers and duties needed to administer and enforce the provisions of this article.

container.heading: Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation

section.heading: CHAP established.
section.text: There is a Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation, constituted as an independent unit of the Department of Planning.

para.heading: General.
para.text: The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation comprises 13 members.

para.heading: Appointed members.
para.text: 11 members are appointed by the Mayor, in accordance with City Charter Article IV, § 6, as follows:
1 member to be nominated by the Greater Baltimore Committee;
1 member to be nominated by Baltimore Heritage;
1 member to be nominated by the Board of Directors of Preservation Maryland;
1 member to be nominated by the Board of the Baltimore City Historical Society, Inc.; and
7 members appointed at-large.
1 member is a Councilmember, to be designated by the Council President.
1 member is the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Each member:
must be a resident of Baltimore City; and
must demonstrate a special interest, knowledge, or training in such fields as history, architecture, preservation, African-American history, or urban design.

para.heading: Appointed members.
para.text: Of the 11 members appointed by the Mayor under § 2-2(b) {"Composition: Appointed members"} of this subtitle:
at least 1 member must be an historian knowledgeable in the architecture, history, and culture of Baltimore City;
at least 1 member must be an historian knowledgeable in the African-American history and culture of Baltimore City;
at least 2 members must be licensed architects knowledgeable in architectural preservation;
at least 1 member must be a licensed real estate broker doing business in Baltimore City;
at least 1 member must own and occupy a contributing residence within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District;
at least 1 member must own and operate a contributing commercial property within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District; and

each of at least 2 different members must demonstrate a special interest, knowledge, or training in 1 of the following fields, not otherwise within the special interest, knowledge, or training of the other member:
landscape architecture;
archeology; and
construction or engineering.

Each of the 11 members appointed under § 2-2(b) {"Composition: Appointed members"} of this subtitle serves for a term concurrent with the Mayor's term of office and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Councilmember designated under § 2-2(c)(1) {"Composition: City representatives"} of this subtitle serves a term concurrent with that Councilmember's service on the Council.

para.heading: Filling vacancy.
para.text: A member appointed to fill a vacancy in an unexpired term serves for the remainder of that term.

para.heading: Term limits.
para.text: A member may not be appointed under § 2-2(b) or (c)(1) of this subtitle to serve more than 2 consecutive terms.

para.heading: Removal on failure to attend meetings.

para.text: Any member who, during any period of 12 consecutive months, fails to attend 6 regularly scheduled monthly meetings of the Commission is considered to have resigned.
The Chair of the Commission must forward the member's name to the member's appointing authority as soon as practicable following the 6th unattended meeting.
The appointing authority must then appoint a successor for the rest of the term.
The Mayor designates one of the Commission members to serve as the Commission's Chair.
The Commission elects one of the Commission members to serve as the Commission's Vice-Chair.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: The members of the Commission:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.
The Executive Director for Historical and Architectural Preservation is appointed by the Commission.
The appointment must be made from a list of at least 3 qualified candidates provided by the Director of Planning.
If the list is not satisfactory to the Commission, the Director of Planning must provide a new list until a satisfactory list of candidates is submitted.

The candidates must meet the qualifications specified in a position description developed by the Commission that conforms to the "Professional Qualifications Standards" of the Secretary of the Interior's "Standards and Guidelines for Archeology and Historic Preservation".
The Executive Director may not also serve as a member of the Commission.

para.heading: General duties.
para.text: The Executive Director:
must perform the duties set forth in this article and as otherwise required by the Commission; and
also serves as Division Chief of the Planning Department's Historical and Architectural Division.

para.heading: Suspension or dismissal.
para.text: The Director of Planning, with the approval of a majority of the Commission, may suspend or dismiss the Executive Director.
The Department of Planning serves as staff to the Commission.

Staff serving in the Planning Department's Historical and Architectural Preservation Division must meet the qualifications of a position description that conforms to the "Professional Qualifications Standards" of the Secretary of the Interior's "Standards and Guidelines for Archeology and Historic Preservation".

para.heading: Consultants.
para.text: The Commission may employ consultants and other personnel necessary or appropriate for the proper performance of its duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.
7 members constitute a quorum for the transaction of business by the Commission.
An affirmative vote of a majority of a quorum is needed for any Commission action.
All meetings of the Commission must be conducted in accordance with the State Open Meetings Act, Title 3 of the State General Provisions Article.
The Commission shall keep records of all its proceedings, showing the vote of each member on each question or, if a member is absent or fails to vote, indicating that fact.
The Commission shall keep a record of all resolutions, transactions, findings, determinations, and decisions.
All records of the Commission are open to public inspection in accordance with the State Public Information Act, Title 4 of the State General Provisions Article.

It is the intent of the Mayor and City Council that the annual Ordinance of Estimates appropriate an adequate sum of money that the Commission may expend for or in connection with the purposes contemplated by this article.
These purposes include:
preparing surveys and maintaining an inventory of historically or architecturally noteworthy structures in Baltimore City;
recommending the designation of and providing for the perpetual protection of:
preservation and conservation districts, as designated under Subtitle 3 {"Designation of Preservation Districts and Conservation Districts"} of this article; and
individual structures that have special historical or architectural significance, as designated under Subtitle 4 {"Designation of Landmarks"} of this article;

recommending the designation of and providing for the temporary protection of individual structures that have historical or architectural significance, as designated under Subtitle 5 {"Designation of Potential Landmarks"} of this article;

reviewing and determining the appropriateness of proposed alterations to or affecting protected properties, as provided in Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc., to or Affecting Properties"} of this article;
acquiring, restoring, and possible reselling of properties that have historical or architectural significance;
implementing the incentive improvement program authorized by § 2-10 {"Incentive improvement program"} of this subtitle; and
general administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and of any other duties imposed on the Commission by law.

para.heading: Grants, loans, etc.
para.text: The Commission may, on behalf of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore and with the prior approval of the Board of Estimates, contract with or accept any grant, loan, or aid of any kind from any federal, state, or private source, to be expended for the purposes contemplated by this article, including the purposes listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section.

para.heading: Proceeds from resale of properties.
para.text: If permitted by the City Charter, sums received from the resale of properties acquired and restored by or on behalf of the Commission may be retained by the Commission for the acquisition and restoration of additional properties.

para.heading: Program established.
para.text: There is an incentive improvement program, as provided in this section.

para.heading: Scope of program.
para.text: Subject to appropriations by the Ordinance of Estimates, the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation may contract with the owner or lessee of a structure that is located within a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or a Historical Conservation District or included on the Landmark List to reimburse that owner or lessee of up to 20% of the cost incurred by her or him in the reconstruction, alteration, removal, repair, or painting of an architectural feature in a manner that furthers the purposes of this article.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: In no event may the Commission authorize any reimbursement under the program until all of the work to be done and the estimated cost of that work has been approved by the Commission.

para.heading: Commission discretion.
para.text: In all cases, the Commission retains full discretion to determine the scope, nature, and cost of all work subject to reimbursement under the program.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation must adopt, after notice and a public hearing, rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this article.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of this section to refer to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

container.heading: Designation of Preservation Districts and Conservation Districts

para.heading: Ordinance required.
para.text: An ordinance of the Mayor and City Council is required to:
designate any area as a Historical and Architectural Preservation District;
designate any area as a Historical Conservation District;
modify the boundary lines of an existing Historical and Architectural Preservation District; or
modify the boundary lines of an existing Historical Conservation District.

para.heading: Findings of fact.
para.text: The ordinance must be supported by written findings of fact that the proposed Preservation District or Conservation District and its boundaries will comply with:
the requirements for Local Government Certification under the National Historic Preservation Act (16 U.S.C., Chapter 1A, Subchapter II);
the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Identification and Registration; and
the Commission's own Historic Preservation Procedures and Guidelines.

section.heading: Initial study and proposal by CHAP.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After undertaking a full and proper study, the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation may propose as a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or as a Historical Conservation District any area in Baltimore City within which are located structures that have historical or architectural value, the preservation of which is considered to be for the educational, cultural, economic, and general welfare of the public.

para.heading: Historical Conservation District
para.text: For a Historical Conservation District, the study shall include consideration of those alterations in which CHAP has design review authority pursuant to City Code Article 6, Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc., to or Affecting Properties"}.

section.heading: CHAP to prepare proposed ordinance and findings.
section.text: In support of its proposed designation of an area, the Commission must:

para.text: prepare a proposed ordinance that sets forth the boundary lines of the area being proposed for designation;
prepare and adopt written findings of fact that include, at a minimum, the specific findings required by § 3-1(b) {"Ordinance ... required: Findings of fact"} of this subtitle; and
request that its proposed ordinance and accompanying findings of fact be introduced into the City Council for appropriate action.
The provisions of this subsection apply to an ordinance proposing any of the following:
designating a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or Historical Conservation District;
modifying the boundaries of an existing Historical and Architectural Preservation District or Historical Conservation District.
An ordinance proposing one of the actions listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be referred by the City Council to the following for a written report and recommendation:
the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation;
the Planning Commission; and
any other agency that the Council President designates.

para.heading: Reports, etc., prerequisite to second reading.
para.text: The City Council may not place the bill on the Council's second reading calendar until the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation and the Planning Commission:
submit their reports and recommendations to the Council; or
fail to do so within 100 days of the referral.

section.heading: Council action – Public notice and hearing.

para.heading: Hearing required.
para.text: The City Council may not place the bill on its second reading calendar until the Council committee to which the bill is assigned has conducted a public hearing at which parties in interest and the general public are afforded an opportunity to be heard on the bill.

para.heading: Notice required.
para.text: Notice of the hearing must be given as follows:
by posting in conspicuous places, as the Department of Planning designates, within and around the following, as the case may be:
the perimeter of the proposed new District; or
the perimeter of any area proposed to be added to or removed from an existing district; and
by first-class mail to each person who appears on the tax records of the City as an owner of property within the following, as the case may be:
the perimeter of the proposed new District; or
the perimeter of any area proposed to be added to or removed from an existing District.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The notice must include:
the identifying number of the bill to be heard;
the name and address of the person requesting the bill;
the date, time, place, and purpose of the public hearing; and
a drawing or description of the boundaries of the area affected by the proposed bill.

para.heading: Timing of notice.
para.text: The notice must be posted and mailed at least 30 days before the public hearing.

para.heading: Number and manner of posted notices.
para.text: The number of posted notices and the manner of their posting are as follows:
at least 2 or more signs are required, as the Department of Planning designates;
for a notice applicable only to an individual property, at least 1 sign must be visible from each of the property's street frontages;
each sign must be posted at a prominent location, near the sidewalk or public right-of-way, so that it is visible to passing pedestrians and motorists;
a window-mounted sign must be mounted inside the window glass and placed so that it is clearly visible to passing pedestrians and motorists; and
each sign must be at least 3 feet by 4 feet in size.

para.heading: Responsibility for notice.
para.text: The notices required by this section are the responsibility of the following:
for a bill requested by the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation, the notices must be given by and at the expense of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore;

for a bill requested by or on behalf of a property owner to include that property in or remove that property from an existing District, the notices must be given by and at the expense of the requester; and
in all other cases, the notices must be given by and at the expense of the City Council.

section.heading: Council action – Disposition.
section.text: Subject to the requirements of § 3-8 {"Council action – Amendments"} and § 3-9 {"Council action – Limitations"} of this subtitle, the City Council may:

para.text: adopt, reject, or modify an ordinance proposed to designate:
a Historical and Architectural Preservation District; or
a Historical Conservation District; and
as necessary or appropriate from time to time, adopt an ordinance to modify the boundary lines of an existing District.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies to any bill that:
proposes to designate a new Preservation District or Conservation District or modify the boundaries of an existing Preservation District or Conservation District; and

that has a proposed amendment to add to or remove from a new or existing District any property that was not within the perimeter of the area described in the notice given under § 3-6 {"Council action - Public notice and hearing"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: New notice and hearing required.
para.text: Before an amendment described in subsection (a) of this section may be adopted:
another public hearing must be held on the amendment; and
the requirements of this subtitle for notice and for agency reports apply to the additional hearing.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies to any of the following actions by the City Council:
any modification to the boundary lines set forth in an ordinance proposed by the Commission under § 3-3 {"CHAP to prepare proposed ordinance and findings"} of this subtitle; or
unless by and in accordance with an ordinance initiated at the request of the Commission under this subtitle:
any initial designation of an area as:
a Historical and Architectural Preservation District; or
a Historical Conservation District; or
any modification to the boundary lines of an existing:
Historical and Architectural Preservation District; or
Historical Conservation District.

para.heading: Referral to CHAP.
para.text: The City Council may not take any action described in subsection (a) of this section without first referring that action to the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation for:
the Commission's written report and recommendations; and

the Commission's findings of fact affirming, at a minimum, that the proposed action will not adversely affect the District's compliance with the requirements, standards, procedures, and guidelines specified in § 3-1(b) {"Ordinance ... required: Findings of fact"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Action by Council.
para.text: If, within 100 days of the referral, the Commission fails to submit its written report or recommendations, or fails or is unwilling to make the findings of fact required by § 3-1(b) {"Ordinance ... required: Findings of fact"} of this subtitle, the City Council:
may proceed to hear and consider the action, subject to the requirements of § 3-6 {"Council action – Public notice and hearing"} and § 3-8 {"Council action – Amendments"} of this subtitle; but

may not adopt the action without preparing and adopting its own written findings of fact affirming that the action will not adversely affect the District's compliance with the requirements, standards, procedures, and guidelines specified in § 3-1(b) {"Ordinance ... required: Findings of fact"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: List components.
section.text: The Landmark List consists of two components:

para.text: a Landmark List: Exteriors; and
a Landmark List: Public Interiors.

section.heading: Ordinance required.
section.text: An ordinance of the Mayor and City Council is required to:

para.text: add a structure and its appurtenant property to the Landmark List: Exteriors or the Landmark List: Public Interiors; or
for a structure already on the Landmark List: Exteriors, to modify the boundaries of the appurtenant land or other property that is included in the Landmark designation.

The Landmark List: Exteriors comprises those structures that, in accordance with the Commission's Historic Preservation Procedures and Guidelines, are considered to be of such special historical or architectural significance that, even if not located within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District, those structures and their exteriors (with or without, as the case may be, their appurtenant land and other property) should be extended the same protections as apply to structures within a District.
The boundaries of a structure on the Landmark List: Exteriors are as indicated by Ordinance, as follows:
by street address, which indicates that all appurtenant land or other property at that street address and on the same lot is included in and protected by the Landmark designation;
by Section, Block, and Lot Number, which indicates that all land or other property on that lot is included in the Landmark designation; or
by a metes and bounds description or other clear delineation, which indicates that less than all land or other property at a street address or on a lot is included in the Landmark designation.

para.heading: Landmark List: Public Interiors.
para.text: The Landmark List: Public Interiors comprises those structures with public interiors that, in accordance with the Commission's Historic Preservation Procedures and Guidelines, are considered to be of such special historical or architectural significance that, even if not within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District, those interiors should be extended the same protections as apply to the exteriors of structures within a District.

para.heading: Required referrals.
para.text: On introduction of any proposed ordinance to add a structure to the Landmark List: Exteriors or Landmark List: Public Interiors or to modify the boundaries of a structure on the Landmark List: Exteriors, the City Council must refer the bill to the following for their written reports and recommendations:
the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation;
the Planning Commission; and
any other agency that the Council President designates.

para.heading: Reports, etc., prerequisite to second reading.
para.text: The City Council may not place the bill on the Council's second reading calendar until the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation and the Planning Commission:
submit their reports and recommendations to the Council; or
fail to do so within 100 days of the referral.

section.heading: Council action – Public notice and hearing.

para.heading: Hearing required.
para.text: The City Council may not place the bill on its second reading calendar until the Council committee to which the bill is assigned has conducted a public hearing at which parties in interest and the general public are afforded an opportunity to be heard on the bill.

para.heading: Notice required.
para.text: Notice of the hearing must be given as follows:
by posting in a conspicuous place on the subject property; and
by first-class mail to each person who appears on the tax records of the City as an owner of the subject property.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The notice must include:
the identifying number of the bill to be heard;
the name and address of the person requesting the bill;
the date, time, place, and purpose of the public hearing; and
the address of the subject property.

para.heading: Timing of notice.
para.text: The notice must be posted and mailed at least 15 days before the public hearing.

para.heading: Number and manner of posted notices.
para.text: The number of posted notices and the manner of their posting are as follows:
at least 1 sign must be visible from each of the property's street frontages;
each sign must be posted at a prominent location, near the sidewalk or public right-of-way, so that it is visible to passing pedestrians and motorists;
a window-mounted sign must be mounted inside the window glass and placed so that it is clearly visible to passing pedestrians and motorists; and
each sign must be at least 3 feet by 4 feet in size.

para.heading: Responsibility for notice.
para.text: The notices required by this section are the responsibility of the following:
for a bill requested by the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation, the notices must be given by and at the expense of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore;
for a bill requested by or on behalf of an owner of the subject property, the notices must be given by and at the expense of the requester; and
in all other cases, the notices must be given by and at the expense of the City Council.

section.heading: Council action – Disposition.
section.text: Subject to the requirements of § 4-8 {"Council action – Limitations"} of this subtitle, the City Council may:

para.text: adopt, reject, or modify an ordinance proposed to add a structure to the Landmark List: Exteriors or the Landmark List: Public Interiors; and
as necessary or appropriate from time to time, adopt an ordinance to modify the boundaries of a structure on the Landmark List: Exteriors.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section applies to any of the following actions by the City Council:
any modification to the boundaries of a structure proposed by the Commission for addition to the Landmark List: Exteriors, as provided in § 4-3(a) {"Landmark List: exteriors"} of this subtitle; or
unless by and in accordance with an ordinance initiated at the request of the Commission under this subtitle:
any initial proposal to add a structure to the Landmark List: Exteriors or the Landmark List: Public Interiors; or
any modification to the boundaries of a structure on the Landmark List Exteriors.

para.heading: Referral to CHAP.
para.text: The City Council may not take any action described in subsection (a) of this section without first referring that action to the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation for the Commission's written report and recommendations.

para.heading: Action by Council.
para.text: If, within 100 days of the referral, the Commission fails to submit its written report or recommendations, the City Council may proceed to hear and consider the action, subject to the requirements of § 4-6 {"Council action – Public notice and hearing"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: List components.
section.text: The Potential-Landmark List consists of two components:

para.text: a Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors; and
a Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors.

section.heading: CHAP to designate.
section.text: Only the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation may:

para.text: add a structure and its appurtenant property to the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors or the Potential-Landmark List: Public interiors; or
for a structure already on the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors, modify the boundaries of the appurtenant land or other property that is included in the Potential-Landmark designation.

The Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors comprises those structures that, in accordance with the Commission's Historic Preservation Procedures and Guidelines, the Commission considers to be of such historical or architectural significance that, even if not located within a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or a Historical Conservation District, those structures and their exteriors (with or without, as the case may be, their appurtenant land and other property) should be extended temporary protection under § 5-5 {"Protections pending decision"} of this subtitle and under Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc, to or Affecting Properties"} of this article.
The boundaries of a structure on the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors are as indicated by the Commission, as follows:
by street address, which indicates that all appurtenant land or other property at that street address and on the same lot is included in and protected by the Potential-Landmark designation;
by Section, Block, and Lot Number, which indicates that all land or other property on that lot is included in the Potential-Landmark designation; or

by a metes and bounds description or other clear delineation, which indicates that less than all land or other property at a street address or on a lot is included in the Potential-Landmark designation.

para.heading: Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors.
para.text: The Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors comprises those structures with public interiors that, in accordance with the Commission's Historic Preservation Procedures and Guidelines, the Commission considers to be of such historical or architectural significance that, whether or not within a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or a Historical Conservation District, those public interiors should be extended temporary protection under § 5-5 {"Protections pending decision"} of this subtitle and under Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc, to or Affecting Properties"} of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A proposal to add a structure to the Potential-Landmark List must comply with the following procedures.
The Commission's Chair or the Executive Director must give notice of a public hearing to be held by the Commission on the proposal, as follows:
by causing a sign to be conspicuously posted on the structure; and
by first-class mail to each person who appears on the tax records of the City as an owner of the subject property.
The notice must include:

a statement that the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation proposes to add the structure to the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors or Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors, as the case may be;
the proposed date, time, and place of the public hearing to be held on the proposal; and
the Commission's contact information (including a phone number) for obtaining additional information on the proposal and updated information on the date, time, and place of the hearing.

para.heading: Timing of hearing.
para.text: The public hearing must be held on a date that is:
no sooner than 30 days from the time the sign is posted; and
except as agreed to by the owner of the subject property, no later than 60 days from the time the sign is posted.

para.heading: Final decision.
para.text: At the end of the public hearing, the Commission must render its decision on whether to include the structure on the Potential-Landmark List.

section.heading: Protections pending decision.
section.text: From the time the sign is posted until the Commission makes its final decision, the structure is subject to the requirements, procedures, and protections of Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc., to or affecting Properties"} of this article.

section.heading: Expiration of designation.
section.text: The inclusion of any property in the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors or the Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors, as the case may be, automatically expires:

para.text: on the 180th day after the Commission's decision to add the structure to that List, unless, before that date, a proposed ordinance is introduced into the City Council to add the structure to the Landmark List: Exteriors or the Landmark List: Public Interiors, respectively; or
if a proposed Landmark ordinance is introduced into the City Council before that 180th day but has not yet been enacted, 18 months from the date of the proposed ordinance's introduction.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This section applies to:

any property for which notice of its proposed addition to the Potential-Landmark List was posted under § 5-4 {"Procedure to designate"} of this article, but for which no final decision to include it on the List was rendered within the period required by that section; or
any property that was included on the Potential-Landmark List, but whose designation has expired by operation of § 5-6 {"Expiration of designation"} of this article.

para.heading: General prohibition.
para.text: Except as expressly permitted in subsection (c) of this section, the Commission may not:
re-propose the addition or reinstatement to the Potential-Landmark List of any property described in subsection (a) of this section; or
initiate a proposed ordinance to add that property to the Landmark List.

The Commission may again propose to add or reinstate the property to the Potential-Landmark List, subject again to the procedures and other provisions of this subtitle, only after the first to occur of:
2 years from the date on which the previous proposal failed or the designation expired, as the case may be;
the election and start of a new 4-year term of office for the members of the City Council; or
the City Council's passage of a simple resolution requesting or authorizing the Commission to do so.

The Commission may initiate proceedings to add the structure to the Landmark List, subject to the procedures and other provisions of Subtitle 4 {"Designation of Landmarks"} of this article, only after the first to occur of:
2 years from the date on which the previous proposal failed or the designation expired, as the case may be;
the election and start of a new 4-year term of office for the members of the City Council; or
the City Council's passage of a simple resolution requesting or authorizing the Commission to do so.

section.heading: CHAP to maintain Inventory.
section.text: The Commission's Executive Director shall create and maintain an Inventory of Historic Places, to identify areas or structures that, while not designated as Preservation Districts, Conservation Districts, Landmarks, or Potential Landmarks, are nonetheless historically or architecturally noteworthy.

section.heading: Purpose of Inventory.
section.text: The primary purpose of the Inventory is to serve as a research and documentation instrument that informs and provides guidance to the Department of Planning and the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Except only as otherwise expressly provided in this article, the Inventory is not a regulatory instrument.

para.heading: No determination of eligibility for designation.
para.text: Inclusion of an area or structure in the Inventory is not a determination of eligibility for designation as a Preservation District, Conservation District, Landmark, or Potential Landmark.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle applies to any land or other property within the boundaries of a structure on the Landmark List: Exteriors or the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors.

section.heading: Effect of subdivision.
section.text: If any land or other property subject to this subtitle is subdivided, all lots, plats, sites, or other divisions land resulting from the subdivision are automatically considered to retain the same Landmark or Potential-Landmark designation and protection as the original site had before its subdivision.

section.heading: Planning Commission to notify CHAP of subdivision.
section.text: As soon as possible after a Final Subdivision Plan has been recorded for any land or other property subject to this subtitle:

para.text: the Planning Commission must submit a copy of the approved Plan to the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation; and
The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation must:
update its records accordingly; and
request the Department of Legislative Reference to insert an Editor's Note to the appropriate section of Subtitle 13 et seq. of this article to indicate any change in the relevant description.

container.heading: Alterations, etc., to or Affecting Properties

para.heading: General.
para.text: The rules and regulations adopted by the Commission under this article:
must include design guidelines for undertaking regulated alterations; and

may include provisions delegating to the Executive Director or other Commission staff the authority to review and approve regulated alterations that involve only minor work, as defined in subsection (b) of this section.

para.heading: "Minor work" defined.
para.text: "Minor work" means work that:
does not significantly change the overall appearance of or remove historic fabric; and
clearly meets the applicable design guidelines adopted by the Commission under this article.

para.heading: Exterior structures.
para.text: No person may undertake, cause, or allow any of the following regulated alterations for or with respect to any structure located within a Historical and Architectural Preservation District or a Historical Conservation District or included on the Landmark List: Exteriors or the Potential-Landmark List: Exteriors without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Building Official:
any reconstruction, alteration, or removal of any exterior architectural feature;
any change in an exterior color, whether by painting or other means;
any exterior excavation;
the construction or erection of any exterior building, fence, wall, or other structure of any kind; or
any exterior demolition.

para.heading: Public interiors.
para.text: No person may undertake, cause, or allow any of the following regulated alterations for or with respect to any structure on the Landmark List: Public Interiors or the Potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Building Official:
any reconstruction, alteration, or removal of any interior architectural feature, as defined in subsection (c) of this section;
any change in an interior color, whether by painting or other means;
any interior excavation;
the construction or erection of any interior wall or other structure of any kind; or
any interior demolition.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, "interior architectural feature" means the architectural style, design, general arrangement, and components of a designated interior.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Interior architectural feature" includes the kind, color, and texture of the building material and the type and style of windows, doors, lights, signs, plaques, decorative finishes, murals, art work, floor plan, and other fixtures appurtenant to the interior.

para.heading: Referral by Building Official.
para.text: Within 2 days of receiving a permit application for or involving a regulated alteration, the Building Official must forward the application, together with all accompanying plans and specifications, to the Commission.

On request of the Commission or its staff, the applicant must submit to the Commission any additional plans, elevations, and other related information needed to determine the appropriateness of the proposed regulated alteration.
The Commission may not make any determination concerning the proposed regulated alteration until it is satisfied that:
the permit application is complete; and
the Commission has received all other needed documents and information, as requested.

para.heading: CHAP approval prerequisite for permit.
para.text: The Building Official may not issue a permit for any regulated alteration unless:
for a Historical Preservation District, the Director first issues an Authorization to Proceed; or
for a Historical Conservation District:
The Director first issues an Authorization to Proceed; or
CHAP makes the determination that the proposed exterior alteration does not require an Authorization to Proceed and notifies the applicant and building official of CHAP's determination.

para.heading: Posting notice.
para.text: If an Authorization to Proceed is not issued within 11 days of the Commission's having received a completed application, the Executive Director must cause a sign to be conspicuously posted on the structure involved, giving notice of:
the type of alterations proposed; and
the date, time, and place of a public hearing to be held by the Commission on the proposal.

para.heading: Hearing.
para.text: The public hearing must be held:
at the next regular Commission meeting scheduled for a date that is no sooner than 10 days nor later than 45 days from the time the sign is posted; or
if no regular meeting has been scheduled for that period, at a special meeting called for a date that is no sooner than 10 days nor later than 20 days from the time the sign is posted.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Within 21 days after the public hearing concludes, or within any additional time that the applicant approves in writing, the Commission must determine whether to approve or deny the issuance of an Authorization to Proceed.

para.heading: Criteria for Authorization to Proceed.
para.text: The Commission may approve issuance of an Authorization to Proceed only if it determines that:

the proposed regulated alteration is compliant with the Commission's design guidelines and otherwise appropriate to the preservation of the particular Preservation District or to the preservation of the structure on the Landmark List or Potential-Landmark List; or
notwithstanding that the proposed regulated alteration is, in the opinion of the Commission, noncompliant with the Commission's design guidelines or otherwise inappropriate:
the proposed alteration nonetheless is without substantial detriment to the public welfare and without substantial derogation of the intents and purposes of this article; and
denial of an Authorization to Proceed would result in substantial hardship to the applicant.

para.heading: Factors to be considered.
para.text: In passing on appropriateness, the Commission must consider, among other pertinent factors:
the structure's historic or architectural significance;
the location and visibility of the proposed alteration; and

the historic or architectural significance, architectural style, general design, arrangement, texture, material, color, architectural features, height, massing, and scale of other structures in the immediate neighborhood.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: If the Commission approves the issuance of an Authorization to Proceed, the Executive Director must promptly issue the Authorization to Proceed and forward it to the Building Official, along with the related application, plans, and specifications.

para.heading: Contents of Authorization to Proceed.
para.text: The Authorization to Proceed must contain:
a description of the regulated alteration being approved;
a reference to whether the approval is premised on:
a finding that the alteration is compliant with the design guidelines and is otherwise appropriate (as required by § 8-6(b)(1) of this subtitle); or
a finding that the alteration is noncompliant or otherwise inappropriate, but:
it is without substantial detriment to the public welfare and without substantial derogation of this article (as required by § 8-6(b)(2)(i) of this subtitle); and
denial would result in substantial hardship to the applicant (as required by § 8-6(b)(2)(ii) of this subtitle);

the substance of any conditions, restrictions, or limitations imposed by the Commission to minimize the degree to which the alteration otherwise would be noncompliant with the Commission's design guidelines or otherwise inappropriate; and
the date on which the Authorization to Proceed is issued.

para.heading: Term of Notice.
para.text: Unless an extension is granted, every Authorization to Proceed expires and becomes invalid if a building permit is not obtained and the work authorized begun within 1 year after the Authorization to Proceed is issued.

section.heading: Denial of Authorization to Proceed – Districts and Landmarks.
section.text: In the case of a structure located within a Preservation District or a Historical Conservation District or included on the Landmark List, if the Commission determines that an Authorization to Proceed should not be issued, the Commission shall promptly notify the applicant and the Building Official in writing of:

para.text: the reason for that determination; and
any recommendations that the Commission might have about the proposed alteration.

section.heading: Denial of Authorization to Proceed – Potential Landmarks.

para.heading: Commission to notify Building Official.
para.text: In the case of a structure on the Potential-Landmark List, if the Commission determines that the proposed regulated alteration is inappropriate, the Commission must notify the Building Official in writing to postpone issuance of the permit.

para.heading: Building Official to postpone.
para.text: If the Building Official is so notified, the Building Official must postpone issuance of the permit until the first to occur of:
180 days from the date of the notification to postpone; or
a subsequent notification by the Commission to issue the permit.

para.heading: Commission to consult with applicant and others.
para.text: During the period of postponement, the Commission must meet with the applicant and may consult with civic groups, public agencies, and interested persons to ascertain what the City can do to preserve the structure.

section.heading: Building Official bound by CHAP decision.
section.text: The Building Official is bound by the Commission's determinations under this subtitle and must approve, if otherwise in conformance with the Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, or disapprove the application for the proposed alteration in accordance with those determinations.

para.heading: "Municipal structure" defined.
para.text: In this section, "municipal structure" means any structure that:
is owned by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore; and
either:
has been or is being used for a municipal function, including offices and other work places, schools, fire stations, police stations, monuments, water and waste water facilities, and the like;
has been or is being aggregated by or for the City for redevelopment under authority of a Master Plan or Urban Renewal Plan; or
meets any other criteria adopted by Commission rule or regulation for structures requiring review under this section.

para.heading: Submission of plans to Commission.
para.text: Before any City action is taken to approve or otherwise authorize the reconstruction, exterior alteration, interior alteration of an area customarily open or accessible to the public, or demolition of any municipal structure, the agency responsible for preparing the plans must refer the plans to the Commission for a report.
The Commission's report must be submitted to the Mayor and to the responsible agency within 45 days after the referral.
If the Commission does not report within this 45-day period, the Mayor may conclude that the Commission does not object to the approval or authorization of the plans.

para.heading: No change in design, etc.
para.text: Nothing in this article prevents the ordinary maintenance or repair of an architectural feature within any Preservation District or any Conservation District or on any Landmark or Potential Landmark, if the maintenance or repair involves no change in design, material, color, or appearance of the structure.

para.heading: Public safety needs.
para.text: Nothing in this article prevents the construction, reconstruction, alteration, or demolition of any feature that the Building Official certifies as being required for public safety because of an unsafe or dangerous condition.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: Within 30 days after CHAP has approved, disapproved, or delayed an application presented at a CHAP public hearing, a person aggrieved by any decision of the Commission under this article may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the Court's final decision to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Unlawful acts.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to be in conflict with or in violation of any provision of this article or of any rule, regulation, decision, permit, notice, or order issued under this article.

para.heading: Enforcement and penalties.
para.text: This article and the rules, regulations, decisions, permits, notices, and orders issued under this article may be enforced by the Building Official and penalties may be imposed for violations of their provisions as provided in Chapter 1 {"Scope and Administration"} of the Baltimore City Building Code for the enforcement of and the imposition of violation penalties under that Code.

section.heading: Injunctions.
section.text: On application of the Commission, the District Court or the Circuit Court for Baltimore City may:

para.text: restrain or enjoin the alteration of any structure in violation of this article; and
order:
the removal of any architectural feature constructed or reconstructed in violation of this article; or
the substantial restoration of any architectural feature altered or demolished in violation of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this article or of any rule, regulation, decision, permit condition, notice, or order issued under this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: Seton Hill District.
section.text: The area located within the boundaries set forth in this section is hereby declared to be an Historical and Architectural Preservation District, and may be referred to as "Seton Hill Historical and Architectural Preservation District":

Beginning for the same at the point formed by the intersection of the center line of Eutaw Street, as now laid out 66 feet wide and the center line of Franklin Street, as now laid out 66 feet wide, and running thence binding on the center line of said Franklin Street and crossing Paca Street westerly 760 feet, more or less, to intersect the center line of Pennsylvania Avenue, as now laid out; thence binding on the center line of said Pennsylvania Avenue northwesterly 675 feet, more or less, to intersect the center line of Orchard Street, as now laid out 60 feet wide; thence binding on the center line of said Orchard Street and crossing Tessier Street and Druid Hill Avenue northeasterly 1,150 feet, more or less, to intersect the center line of McCulloh Street, as now laid out 65 feet wide; thence binding on the center line of said McCulloh Street and crossing St. Mary Street South 38°-12'-00" East 415 feet, more or less, to intersect a line drawn parallel with and distant 30.0 feet northeasterly, measured at right angles, from the southwest side of Monument Street, as now laid out; thence binding on said line so drawn southeasterly 135 feet, more or less, to intersect the center line of said Eutaw Street and thence binding on the center line of said Eutaw Street and crossing Druid Hill Avenue and George Street southerly 835 feet, more or less, to the place of beginning.

Beginning for the same at the point formed by the intersection of the northeast face of the southwest concrete curb of Mt. Beginning for the same at the point formed by the intersection of the south side of Lombard Street, as now laid out and the west side of the former bed of Hopkins Place, as condemned and closed under Ordinance No. 679, approved June 14, 1974 and running thence binding on the west side of the former bed of said Hopkins Place, Southerly 27 feet, more or less, to the south outline of the property known as No. 100 Hopkins Place; thence binding on the south outline of said property, Westerly 130 feet, more or less, to the east side of the former bed of a 20 foot alley, as condemned and closed under said ordinance; thence binding on the east side of the former bed of said 20 foot alley, Northerly 27 feet, more or less, to the south side of said Lombard Street and thence binding on the south side of said Lombard Street, Easterly 130 feet, more or less, to the place of beginning.

section.heading: Ridgely's Delight District.
section.text: The area located within the boundaries set forth in this section is hereby declared to be a Historic and Architectural District, and may be referred to as Ridgely's Delight Historical and Architectural Preservation District:

Beginning for the same at the intersection of the north side of West Pratt Street and the center line of the proposed City Boulevard; thence from said point of beginning and binding on the north side of Pratt Street easterly to intersect the east side of Greene Street; thence binding on the east side of Greene Street southerly to intersect the center line of the proposed City Boulevard; thence binding on the center line of the proposed City Boulevard northerly to the point of beginning.
Provided, however, that notwithstanding the provisions hereinabove in this section, the following property is excluded from and is not included in the described area:
The property listed in the Baltimore City Tax records as Lot 1 in Block 676, measuring 289 feet by 280 feet and known as 220 South Greene Street.

section.text: Beginning for the same at the north side of North Avenue and the west side of Jordan Street; thence binding from said point of beginning on the west side of Jordan Street northerly to intersect the north side of the first 3-foot alley south of Chauncey Avenue; section.text: The area located within the boundaries set forth in this section is hereby declared to be a Historical and Architectural Preservation District and may be referred to as the Bancroft Park Historical and Architectural Preservation District:

Beginning for the same at the point formed by the intersection of the southeast side of Bancroft Road, 60 feet wide, and the southeast side of Cross Country Boulevard, 50 feet wide, and running thence binding on the southeast side of said Cross Country Boulevard, Northeasterly 69 feet, more or less; para.heading: PUD review by CHAP.
para.text: The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation shall review plans for Planned Unit Developments in the Fells Point Historic District as follows:

For all Planned Unit Developments (PUDs) established prior to the designation of this district, the height and massing guidelines in the PUD shall govern future development. The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation (CHAP) shall review and approve the building design within the prior approved massing. CHAP's approval is required prior to Planning Commission Final Design Approval.
For any building within an established PUD that has already received Final Design Approval by the Planning Commission, that building is not subject to CHAP approval.
All major amendments to existing PUDs are subject to CHAP approval.
All revised Final Design Approvals are subject to CHAP approval.
If a new PUD is established within the Fells Point Local Historic District, the new PUD shall be subject to CHAP approval.

para.heading: Planned Unit Development review by the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation.
para.text: The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation shall review plans for Planned Unit Developments in the Woodberry Historic District as follows:

For any Planned Unit Development ("PUD") established prior to the designation of the Woodberry Historic District, the height and massing guidelines in the PUD shall govern future development. The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation ("CHAP") shall review and approve the building design within the prior approved massing. CHAP's approval is required prior to Planning Commission Final Design Approval.
For any building within an established PUD that has already received Final Design Approval by the Planning Commission, that building is not subject to CHAP approval.
All amendments to existing PUDs are subject to CHAP approval.
All revised Final Design Approvals are subject to CHAP approval.
If a new PUD is established within the Woodberry Historic District, the new PUD shall be subject to CHAP approval.

para.heading: Buildings that have already received Site Plan Review Committee approval.
para.text: Any building that has received Site Plan Review Committee ("SPRC") approval on or before October 10, 2018, is not subject to CHAP approval.

section.heading: Crimea House, Chapel, and Stables.
section.text: Crimea House, Chapel, and Stables, the Crimea House property being described as follows:

The improvements thereon being known as the Crimea House in Leakin Park.
The Chapel property is described as follows:

Beginning for the same at a point formed by the intersection of the east side of a paved park road and a line drawn parallel with and distant 20 feet northerly from the northernmost side of the building on the lot now being described, known as the Crimea Chapel building, the approximate coordinate of said point being West 23980 feet and North 3583 feet; and running thence binding on said line so drawn easterly 92 feet, more or less, to intersect a line drawn parallel with and distant 20 feet easterly from the easternmost side of said building; thence binding on said line so drawn southerly 71 feet, more or less, to intersect a line drawn parallel with and distant 20 feet southerly from the southernmost side of said building; thence binding on said line so drawn westerly 42 feet, more or less, to intersect the east side of the said paved park road, thence binding on the east side of said road, northerly 74 feet, more or less, to the place of beginning. The improvements thereon being known as the Crimea Chapel in Leakin Park.
The Stable property is described as follows:

Beginning for the same at a point formed by the intersection of the west side of a paved park road and a line drawn parallel with and distant 40 feet northerly from the northernmost side of the building on the lot now being described, known as the Crimea Stable building, the approximate coordinate of said point of beginning being West 24030 feet and North 2940 feet and running thence binding on the west side of said paved park road southerly 130 feet, more or less, to intersect a line drawn parallel with and distant 40 feet southerly from the southernmost side of said building; thence binding on said line so drawn Easterly 146 feet, more or less, to intersect a line drawn parallel with and distant 40 feet westerly from the westernmost side of said building; thence binding on said line so drawn northerly 128 feet, more or less, to intersect the line drawn parallel with and distant 40 feet northerly from the northernmost side of said building, and thence binding on said line so drawn easterly 118 feet, more or less, to the place of beginning. The improvements thereon being known as the Crimea Stable in Leakin Park.
The coordinate mentioned is referred to the true meridian as adopted by the Baltimore Survey Control System.

The improvements thereon being known as the Gates of Greenmount Cemetery.
The Chapel property is described as follows:

Beginning for the same at a point formed by the intersection of a line drawn parallel to the side of and distant 2 feet southeasterly from the southeasternmost point of the side of the carport of the Chapel, and a line drawn parallel to the side of and distant 2 feet southwesterly from the southwesternmost point of the side of said carport, said point of beginning having the approximate coordinate of east 2299 feet and North 3489 feet and running thence binding on said line, drawn parallel to the side of and distant 2 feet southwesterly from the southwesternmost point of the side of said carport, northwesterly 22.5 feet, more or less, to intersect a line drawn parallel with the side of and distant 2 feet northwesterly from the northwesternmost point of said carport, thence binding on said line so drawn northeasterly 18.5 feet, more or less, to intersect a curve whose center is the center of the Chapel, said curve also being concentric with the Chapel, running thence by a line curving to the right with a radius of 25 feet, more or less, the distance of 133 feet, more or less, to intersect said line drawn parallel to the side of and distant 2 feet southeasterly from the southeasternmost point of the side of said carport and thence binding on said line so drawn southwesterly 18.5 feet, more or less, to the place of beginning. The improvements thereon being known as the Greenmount Cemetery Chapel.

section.heading: James Lawrence Kernan Hospital.
section.text: James Lawrence Kernan Hospital, located at 2200 North Forest Park Avenue, the property being further described as follows:

Beginning for the same at a point formed by the intersection of the line of the northeasternmost side of a three story brick building, there situate, if projected southeasterly, and the line of the southeasternmost side of said building if projected northeasterly, said building is part of the James Lawrence Kernan Hospital Site, being the former Mansion House, said point of beginning having the approximate coordinate of West 26458 feet and North 6340 feet, and running thence binding reversely on said last line so projected southwesterly 67 feet, more or less, to intersect the line of the southwesternmost side of said building if projected southeasterly; thence binding reversely on said line so projected northwesterly 59 feet, more or less, to intersect the line of the northwesternmost side of said building if projected southwesterly, thence binding reversely on said line so projected northeasterly 67 feet, more or less, to intersect the line of the northeasternmost side of said building if projected northwesterly and thence binding reversely on said line so projected southeasterly 59 feet, more or less, to the place of beginning. The improvements thereon being known as the James Lawrence Kernan Hospital.
The coordinate mentioned is referred to the true meridian as adopted by the Baltimore Survey Control System.

para.heading: Designation.
para.text: The Olmsted Parkways comprise:
the medians and sidewalks of the 2600-3200 blocks of the Alameda;
the medians and sidewalks of the 0000-1800 blocks of 33rd Street; and
the medians and sidewalks of the 1600-3900 blocks of the Gwynns Falls Parkway.
In accordance with City Code Article 6, §§ 4-9 and 4-11, a building permit is not required for any necessary repair or maintenance of or to these medians and sidewalks.
The Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation will:
review all proposed changes to these medians and sidewalks, except those for necessary repair or maintenance; and
consider traffic, safety, and engineering implications when reviewing these proposed changes.
